questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of bloating and nausea after eating. During this time, he has also had episodic abdominal pain, which increases after meals. He has osteoarthritis of the left knee. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is ibuprofen. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 21 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft; there is mild tenderness to palpation over the epigastrium. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows 3 shallow ulcers of the gastric mucosa. The biopsy specimen shows chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa and Helicobacter pylori. The physician prescribes a 2-week course of antibiotics and omeprazole to treat the H. pylori infection and recommends that the patient avoid drinking alcohol and using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Five weeks later, the patient returns to the office for a follow-up examination. He feels well. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the success of treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A urea breath test is indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication 4–6 weeks after completing treatment. Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole) should be stopped at least 2 weeks before testing because they increase the risk of false negative results. Other tests for confirming eradication include stool antigen testing and rapid urease testing of biopsy samples. The latter is only considered in patients who require follow-up endoscopy (e.g., those with persistent symptoms, dysplasia on biopsy, new onset of symptoms after successful eradication). Acid suppression medications can be discontinued after eradication is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of increasing antibiotic resistance, eradication should be confirmed in all patients who have been treated for an H. pylori infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Because endoscopic follow-up with biopsy (for rapid urease testing) is an invasive procedure, it is only indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication in certain patients with peptic ulcer disease (e.g., to rule out gastric cancer in those with refractory symptoms). This patient should undergo a less invasive procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool testing can be used to confirm H. pylori eradication. However, a stool antigen assay rather than a stool culture is indicated. Stool cultures have no role in the management of H. pylori infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing detects IgG antibodies against H. pylori. However, a positive test cannot distinguish between a past and a current infection. Moreover, because H. pylori antibodies may still be present for weeks or months after treatment and eradication, serologic testing has no utility in confirming the success of treatment.
questions.hint: This patient has peptic ulcer disease associated with H. pylori infection, which is being treated with H. pylori eradication therapy. Antibiotic resistance and/or inadequate adherence can lead to treatment failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of upper abdominal pain and nausea that occurs about 3 hours after eating and at night. The symptoms improve with eating. After eating, he often has a feeling of fullness and bloating. He has had several episodes of dark stools over the past month. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks 2–3 12-oz bottles of beer on most weekdays. He takes no medications. He is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows epigastric tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Which of the following interventions is most likely to be effective in improving this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and alcohol consumption
Tetracycline, metronidazole, bismuth, and omeprazole therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cessation of smoking and alcohol consumption is an important adjunct to treat dyspepsia due to gastritis, pancreatic disorders, and PUD but is not the most effective measure to treat a duodenal ulcer, the majority of which are due to H. pylori infection (especially in individuals who are not taking NSAIDs).

B) CORRECT:

The vast majority of duodenal ulcers are caused by an underlying H. pylori infection (especially in individuals who are not taking NSAIDs). H. pylori eradication therapy (e.g., optimized bismuth quadruple therapy) heals > 90% of duodenal ulcers and prevents further complications, such as rebleeding, perforation, fistulation, and gastric outlet obstruction. This patient should also be counseled on smoking cessation and restricting alcohol intake, as both are important in preventing recurrence.

Clarithromycin triple therapy can be used to treat clarithromycin-sensitive H. pylori infection if first-line treatment is unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

Cholecystectomy would prevent symptoms due to gallstone disease, which can cause dyspeptic symptoms and for which obesity is a risk factor. However, melena would not be expected with gallstone disease, and the abdominal pain due to gallstone disease typically occurs postprandially rather than on an empty stomach and is most commonly localized to the right upper quadrant.

D) INCORRECT:

Exercise and weight loss are effective in improving the symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or hiatus hernia (HH). Patients with GERD or HH can report an aggravation of symptoms at night (due to the recumbent position) but these conditions typically manifest with heartburn and regurgitation. Epigastric pain and GI bleeding are atypical symptoms of GERD or HH. Lifestyle modifications such as exercise and weight loss should be recommended to this patient but are not the most effective measures to treat symptoms due to a duodenal ulcer.

E) INCORRECT:

Acid suppression therapy with a proton pump inhibitor such as pantoprazole is the treatment of choice for H. pylori-negative PUD. However, most duodenal ulcers are related to H. pylori infection (especially in individuals who are not taking NSAIDs). Although monotherapy with pantoprazole might temporarily improve this patient's symptoms, a different approach is more likely to be effective for providing long-term symptom relief and preventing further complications of the disease.
questions.hint: Dyspeptic symptoms (e.g., epigastric pain, bloating) and melena are features of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Epigastric pain that occurs on an empty stomach (e.g., at night, 2–5 hours after meals) and is relieved by eating (leading to weight gain) suggests a duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman from Ecuador is admitted to the hospital because of tarry black stools and epigastric pain for 2 weeks. The epigastric pain is briefly relieved after eating but worsens within 1–2 hours. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Fecal occult blood test is positive. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Biopsy of the gastric antrum and body is performed. Microscopic examination of the biopsy specimens is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

H. pylori is a spiral-shaped, flagellated gram-negative rod that mainly colonizes the antrum of the stomach. This bacterium is catalase positive, oxidase positive, and urease positive.
Image Description:

Scanning electron micrograph of helicobacter pylori

Multiple spiral-shaped bacteria with a length of 3μm and flagella are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Shigella species are short, nonflagellated gram-negative rods that produce Shiga toxin. They are obligate pathogens and cause fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. Shigella spp. are not associated with PUD.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a stool sample

Rod-shaped bacteria (examples in blue overlay) that also occasionally form short chains are visible. Erythrocytes (arrowheads indicate examples) and an inflammatory leukocytic exudate (examples in green overlay) can also be seen.

These findings are consistent with Shigella dysentery.

C) INCORRECT:

C. difficile is a drumstick-shaped, gram-positive rod that is part of the natural gut flora in 5% of adults. Although clostridium enterocolitis may lead to bloody diarrhea, the bacteria is not associated with PUD.

D) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci describes the histological findings of S. pneumoniae, which may cause many conditions (e.g., pneumonia, meningitis, sinusitis) but not gastrointestinal ulcers.
Image Description:

Scanning electron photomicrograph

A joined pair of spherical cocci (diplococci) is visible.

E) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a dimorphic budding yeast forming hyphae and long pseudohyphae. Candida albicans can cause esophagitis in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., HIV, transplant patients, diabetes mellitus) that can also lead to tarry stools if bleeding occurs, but it is not a common cause of PUD.
Image Description:

Typical rod-like, budding structure of Candida albicans (red overlay).

F) INCORRECT:

Giardiasis is a common parasitic infection caused by Giardia lamblia, which in their active form in the human body, appear as teardrop-shaped trophozoites. It presents with voluminous diarrhea characteristically consisting of frothy and greasy stools but is not associated with gastrointestinal bleeding or PUD.
Image Description:

Scanning electron micrograph

The trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia can be seen. Trophozoites are capable of reproduction and have two nuclei (N) in the ventral part as well as flagella (marked with arrows).
questions.hint: This patient presents with a bleeding duodenal ulcer found on esophagogastroduodenoscopy. The most common cause of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is infection with Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-year history of recurrent upper abdominal pain and fullness that worsens after meals. Urea breath test is positive. An endoscopy shows diffuse mucosal atrophy and patchy erythema, but no ulcer. A biopsy from which of the following areas is most likely to yield an accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

H. pylori-induced atrophic gastritis can cause mucosal changes in the fundus, making it an important location to biopsy when H. pylori gastritis is suspected but the heaviest infection with H. pylori is usually seen in another location. The gastric fundus and body are primarily affected in autoimmune atrophic gastritis, which can present similarly but the urea breath test would be negative and other features suggestive of autoimmune disease (e.g., pernicious anemia, vitiligo, autoimmune thyroiditis) would usually be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Distal esophageal biopsies are indicated in patients with treatment-resistant reflux esophagitis to rule out Barrett esophagus and dysplastic changes. This patient's findings, which indicate atrophic gastritis due to H. pylori infection, do not necessitate esophageal biopsy because H. pylori infection is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal carcinoma.

Autoimmune atrophic gastritis is a risk factor for the development of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus and may require further monitoring. However, squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus usually affects the proximal, not distal esophagus.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic atrophic gastritis due to H. pylori infection begins in the gastric antrum (pyloric antrum) and then spreads to other regions such as the fundus and body. Biopsies from the gastric antrum are therefore most likely to yield an accurate diagnosis because atrophic changes and H. pylori infection load is greatest at this site. Gastric MALToma is a potential complication of H. pylori infection. In contrast to H. pylori-induced atrophic gastritis, the gastric fundus and body are primarily affected in autoimmune atrophic gastritis, which can present similarly but the urea breath test would be negative and other features suggestive of autoimmune disease (e.g., pernicious anemia, vitiligo, autoimmune thyroiditis) would usually be present. Patients with atrophic gastritis have decreased gastric acid secretion (hypochlorhydria) with a secondary increase in gastrin levels.

Persistent dyspepsia in a patient over 55 years of age mandates evaluation with an upper endoscopy, even in the absence of alarm symptoms (dysphagia, unintentional weight loss, hematemesis, or melena), to rule out malignant lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

The duodenal bulb is a common location for duodenal ulcers, which are often associated with H. pylori infection. However, upper endoscopy findings in this patient show diffuse gastric mucosal atrophy and inflammation without an ulcer, which is consistent with chronic atrophic gastritis rather than peptic ulcer disease. A different site has the heaviest H. pylori infection load in patients with chronic atrophic gastritis.

E) INCORRECT:

The pylorus is not a common site for atrophic gastritis or for colonization by H. pylori. Pyloric biopsies would be indicated in patients with a pyloric mass causing gastric outlet obstruction. Although this man has early satiety, he lacks other symptoms consistent with gastric outlet obstruction, such as postprandial, nonbilious vomiting, progressive gastric dilation, and weight loss.
questions.hint: This patient with recurrent upper abdominal pain and fullness after meals (dyspepsia), positive urea breath test, and upper endoscopy findings of diffuse mucosal atrophy and patchy erythema, likely has atrophic gastritis caused by Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents for her annual evaluation. She is asymptomatic, but her 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is estimated to be 15%. The physician recommends initiating treatment with rosuvastatin and low-dose aspirin. The patient mentions that her husband was recently diagnosed with Helicobacter pylori infection by a urease breath test and is currently undergoing treatment. She read online that the infection is associated with gastric ulcers and cancer. She requests testing for Helicobacter pylori infection.
What is the most appropriate response to the patient’s request?

choices.text: Recommend Helicobacter pylori antibody serology testing
Recommend a fecal antigen test for Helicobacter pylori infection
Empirically treat for Helicobacter pylori infection
Reassure the patient that Helicobacter pylori testing is unnecessary at this time
Recommend esophagogastroduodenoscopy to biopsy for Helicobacter pylori

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serological testing is not preferred as a first-line test to diagnose H. pylori infection in asymptomatic individuals because it cannot distinguish active from past infections and has a lower diagnostic specificity compared to other methods.

B) CORRECT:

The 2024 American College of Gastroenterology guidelines recommend H. pylori testing in the following scenarios:

• Active peptic ulcer disease or a history of peptic ulcer disease without prior H. pylori eradication therapy
• Uninvestigated dyspepsia
• Gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma
• Endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer
• Unexplained iron deficiency anemia
• Immune thrombocytopenia in adults
• Individuals on chronic NSAID therapy
• Before the initiation of chronic low-dose aspirin therapy
• Adults who share a household with an individual who has been diagnosed with H. pylori infection by a nonserological test

When H. pylori testing is necessary, the tests with the highest positive and negative predictive values are the urea breath test and fecal antigen tests. Serological testing is not preferred as a first-line test to diagnose H. pylori infection in asymptomatic individuals because it cannot distinguish active from past infections and has a lower diagnostic specificity compared to other methods.

It is important to reassure the patient that while H. pylori infection is associated with ulcer disease and certain gastric malignancies — such as gastric adenocarcinoma and gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma — only a very small minority of infected patients develop these complications.

Key learning point: H. pylori testing is recommended before starting chronic low-dose aspirin and for adult household members of those diagnosed with H. pylori infection by a nonserological test.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment for H. pylori infection is no longer recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Previously, testing asymptomatic individuals for H. pylori infection was not recommended. The current American College of Gastroenterology guidelines recommend H. pylori testing before starting chronic low-dose aspirin and for adult household members of those diagnosed with H. pylori infection by a nonserological test.

E) INCORRECT:

A biopsy via esophagogastroduodenoscopy is the first-line test for H. pylori infection when ruling out gastric malignancy is necessary. This approach is typically reserved for patients with dyspepsia who are over the age of 60 years or have alarm features (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding, weight loss, anemia). Invasive H. pylori testing is not recommended as a first-line test in asymptomatic individuals.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents for follow-up 8 weeks after being hospitalized for upper gastrointestinal bleeding. He had not been using nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications.
An upper endoscopy at the time of admission revealed a clean-based duodenal ulcer, and a biopsy showed evidence of Helicobacter pylori infection. He completed a course of bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, tetracycline, and omeprazole 6 weeks ago and is feeling well, with no further bleeding. On examination, his abdomen is soft and nontender.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Repeat upper endoscopy with rapid urease test
Repeat upper endoscopy with biopsy for histology

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The American College of Gastroenterology recommends that eradication of Helicobacter pylori be confirmed in any patient who has an H. pylori-associated ulcer with complications such as bleeding. H. pylori stool antigen testing is a simple method of confirming eradication. It should not be performed until at least 4 weeks after the completion of therapy to avoid false results. A urea breath test can also be used to confirm eradication. Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor should be discontinued 2 weeks before testing.

Key learning point: After therapy for Helicobacter pylori-associated ulcers is completed, eradication of the bacteria should be confirmed with either stool antigen testing or urea breath testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Although both histologic and rapid urease testing can be used at the time of endoscopy for diagnosis of H. pylori infection, they should be performed only if an upper endoscopy is clinically indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Lactulose breath testing is performed to evaluate for small-intestine bacterial overgrowth.

D) INCORRECT:

Although both histologic and rapid urease testing can be used at the time of endoscopy for diagnosis of H. pylori infection, they should be performed only if an upper endoscopy is clinically indicated. A repeat upper endoscopy is recommended for patients with gastric ulcers, to evaluate for potential malignancy, but it is not recommended for patients with duodenal ulcers.

E) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing is not useful for follow-up, given that antibodies can remain positive for years after completion of successful treatment.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man is seen after a recent upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage that required care in the intensive care unit. Upper endoscopy demonstrates a large cratered gastric ulcer (figure). A biopsy of his stomach demonstrates chronic gastritis, with evidence of Helicobacter pylori organisms.
One year ago, the patient was treated for H. pylori infection with triple therapy, including a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin, after he presented with dyspepsia and tested positive for H. pylori stool antigen. He has no history of use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications.
Which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, levofloxacin, and clarithromycin
Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, misoprostol, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin
Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, and tetracycline
Repeat treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin
Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and amoxicillin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A levofloxacin-based regimen is another reasonable salvage regimen in someone with persistent H. pylori infection. However, this regimen consists of a proton pump inhibitor, levofloxacin, and amoxicillin (not clarithromycin).

B) INCORRECT:

Triple therapy consisting of a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin has traditionally been recommended as first-line therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. However, resistance to antibiotic treatment, particularly to clarithromycin, is increasing. As a result, clarithromycin should be avoided in first-line therapy in areas where macrolide resistance is high (likely to be the case for most of North America). Clarithromycin-based triple therapy can still be used as second-line treatment if initial treatment with first-line bismuth-based quadruple therapy fails to achieve eradication.

C) CORRECT:

Triple therapy consisting of a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin has traditionally been recommended as first-line therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. However, resistance to antibiotic treatment, particularly to clarithromycin, is increasing. As a result, clarithromycin should be avoided in first-line therapy in areas where macrolide resistance is high (likely to be the case for most of North America). Current guidelines recommend bismuth-based quadruple therapy, consisting of bismuth subsalicylate, a proton pump inhibitor, metronidazole, and tetracycline, for 10 to 14 days as first-line treatment for H. pylori infection. This regimen is also the most appropriate second-line treatment if initial treatment with triple therapy fails to eradicate the infection. Proton pump inhibitors are considered superior to histamine-2-receptor blockers for treating H. pylori infection.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for Helicobacter pylori infection is standard quadruple therapy (a proton pump inhibitor, bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, and tetracycline).

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat triple therapy with clarithromycin is not optimal because of the potential for the development of clarithromycin resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should not be used in this situation because H. pylori is naturally resistant to it.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports 6 weeks of burning epigastric discomfort that generally develops after a large meal and lasts for 2 to 3 hours. She tried an over-the-counter antacid (calcium carbonate) but did not notice an improvement. She has not lost any weight and reports no melena, passage of bright-red blood, or vomiting. She takes no regular medications.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.1
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
220,000
150,000–350,000


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
34
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
31
0–35


Which one of the following next steps is recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Empiric triple therapy with lansoprazole, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin without testing for Helicobacter pylori infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Noninvasive testing for Helicobacter pylori infection — with either a urea breath test or a fecal antigen detection test — is recommended for patients with new-onset dyspepsia who are younger than 60 years of age. Serologic testing for H. pylori infection is a less accurate indicator of current infection than urea breath testing or stool antigen testing. The urea breath test is most accurate when the patient has been off any proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for at least 2 weeks.

Empiric treatment for H. pylori infection is not recommended; treatment is warranted only if the test result is positive. Current guidelines also do not recommend empiric treatment with PPIs until H. pylori infection has been ruled out.

Key learning point: Patients younger than 60 years of age with new-onset uncomplicated dyspepsia should be evaluated with noninvasive testing (urea breath test or fecal antigen detection) for Helicobacter pylori infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment for H. pylori infection is not recommended; treatment is warranted only if the test result is positive. Current guidelines also do not recommend empiric treatment with PPIs until H. pylori infection has been ruled out.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is appropriate for patients with new-onset dyspepsia who are ≥60 years of age. The American College of Gastroenterology no longer recommends diagnostic endoscopy in patients <60 years of age who have alarm symptoms, such as vomiting or weight loss alone. Notably, this recommendation is conditional, because some patients — such as those with prominent symptoms (e.g., weight loss >9 kg or rapidly progressive dysphagia) or a family history of upper gastrointestinal cancer — will be at higher risk than others, such as patients with vomiting alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for celiac disease could be considered if the patient reported any of the typical features of this disease, such as diarrhea, flatulence, borborygmus, and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH probe testing is not recommended for initial evaluation of dyspepsia because of its low sensitivity and specificity for detecting H. pylori infection as part of a test-and-treat strategy.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man reports a 12-week history of epigastric discomfort that has been unresponsive to a 2-week course of over-the-counter proton pump inhibitor therapy. The patient has no family history of gastric cancer, current use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, weight loss, or gastrointestinal bleeding. Deep palpation of the abdomen reveals epigastric tenderness. The presentation prompts concern for Helicobacter pylori infection.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Endoscopic biopsy with urease testing after proton pump inhibitors have been discontinued for 2 weeks
Helicobacter pylori serology after proton pump inhibitors have been discontinued for 2 weeks
Helicobacter pylori urea breath test without discontinuing proton-pump-inhibitor therapy
Helicobacter pylori fecal antigen test after proton pump inhibitors have been discontinued for 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy is recommended for evaluation of dyspepsia only in patients aged ≥ 60 years. An upper endoscopy can also be considered in younger patients whose symptoms persist after H. pylori eradication and adequate trials of PPIs, tricyclic antidepressants, and prokinetic agents.

B) INCORRECT:

H. pylori serology may be useful in ruling out infection, given its high negative predictive value, but it is the least accurate of the noninvasive testing options.

C) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy is recommended for evaluation of dyspepsia only in patients aged ≥60 years. An upper endoscopy can also be considered in younger patients whose symptoms persist after H. pylori eradication and adequate trials of PPIs, tricyclic antidepressants, and prokinetic agents.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients <60 years of age who present with uncomplicated dyspepsia should undergo noninvasive testing for Helicobacter pylori infection with the fecal antigen or urea breath test. However, patients should not undergo these tests while receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine-2 (H2) receptor antagonists, or antimicrobial therapy, because those treatments can suppress infection and thereby reduce test sensitivity.

E) CORRECT:

Patients <60 years of age who present with uncomplicated dyspepsia should undergo noninvasive testing for Helicobacter pylori infection with the fecal antigen or urea breath test. Both tests perform with >95% sensitivity and specificity. However, patients should not undergo these tests while receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine-2 (H2) receptor antagonists, or antimicrobial therapy, because those treatments can suppress infection and thereby reduce test sensitivity. Diagnostic testing should be delayed 24 hours in patients taking H2-receptor antagonists, 2 weeks in those taking PPIs, and 4 weeks in those taking antimicrobials. If the testing for H. pylori returns positive, the patient should be treated with one of the treatment regimens for this organism, followed by repeat testing to confirm eradication.

An upper endoscopy is recommended for evaluation of dyspepsia only in patients aged ≥60 years. The American College of Gastroenterology no longer recommends diagnostic endoscopy in patients <60 years of age who have so-called alarm features, such as weight loss or vomiting. Notably, this recommendation is conditional, because some patients — such as those with prominent symptoms (e.g., weight loss >9 kg or rapidly progressive dysphagia) or a family history of upper gastrointestinal cancer — will be at higher risk than others, such as patients with vomiting alone. An upper endoscopy can also be considered in younger patients whose symptoms persist after H. pylori eradication and adequate trials of PPIs, tricyclic antidepressants, and prokinetic agents.

Key learning point: The most appropriate noninvasive tests to diagnose Helicobacter pylori infection in a young patient with uncomplicated dyspepsia are either an H. pylori fecal antigen test or an H. pylori urea breath test, performed 2 weeks after use of any proton pump inhibitor is discontinued.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents for follow-up 4 weeks after completing a 14-day course of bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, metronidazole, and omeprazole for endoscopy-confirmed Helicobacter pylori infection. He reports complete resolution of his symptoms, and his physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Follow-up observation, with additional testing if symptoms return

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All patients receiving treatment for H. pylori infection should undergo testing to confirm eradication of infection.

B) INCORRECT:

If a patient does not achieve eradication after two courses of antibiotics, a repeat endoscopy is recommended to obtain biopsies and assess H. pylori antibiotic susceptibility. This patient has had one course of antibiotics and has not yet undergone a test of cure. Thus, repeating endoscopy at this juncture would be unnecessarily invasive and expensive compared with stool or breath testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Urea breath testing is an appropriate noninvasive method to evaluate for H. pylori. In contrast, lactose hydrogen breath testing is used to diagnose lactose intolerance. This patient does not report any symptoms of lactose intolerance.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibody-based testing for H. pylori in the urine, saliva, or blood is not recommended for initial diagnosis or as a test of cure.

E) CORRECT:

Bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, metronidazole, and omeprazole is a guideline-recommended treatment for confirmed Helicobacter pylori infection. The recommended duration of treatment is 10 to 14 days. At the end of this period, the resolution of symptoms is not an indicator of successful therapy, nor is the persistence of symptoms a sign of treatment failure.

All patients receiving treatment for H. pylori infection should undergo testing to confirm eradication of infection. A test of cure — which can consist of either stool antigen testing or urea breath testing — should be conducted at least 4 weeks after completion of therapy to avoid false-negative results.

Key learning point: Patients who have undergone treatment for confirmed H. pylori infection should undergo a test of cure with either urea breath testing or stool antigen testing at least 4 weeks after completion of therapy.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. Five weeks ago, he was prescribed a 2-week course of antibiotics and omeprazole to treat the infection. He feels well. Which of the following is most appropriate for confirming treatment success?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A urea breath test is indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication 4–6 weeks after completing treatment. Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole) should be stopped at least 2 weeks before testing because they increase the risk of false negative results. Other tests for confirming eradication include stool antigen testing and rapid urease testing of biopsy samples. The latter is only considered in patients who require follow-up endoscopy (e.g., those with persistent symptoms, dysplasia on biopsy, new onset of symptoms after successful eradication). Acid suppression medications can be discontinued after eradication is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of increasing antibiotic resistance, eradication should be confirmed in all patients who have been treated for an H. pylori infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Because endoscopic follow-up with biopsy (for rapid urease testing) is an invasive procedure, it is only indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication in certain patients with peptic ulcer disease (e.g., to rule out gastric cancer in those with refractory symptoms). This patient should undergo a less invasive procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool testing can be used to confirm H. pylori eradication. However, a stool antigen assay rather than a stool culture is indicated. Stool cultures have no role in the management of H. pylori infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing detects IgG antibodies against H. pylori. However, a positive test cannot distinguish between a past and a current infection. Moreover, because H. pylori antibodies may still be present for weeks or months after treatment and eradication, serologic testing has no utility in confirming the success of treatment.
questions.hint: This patient is being treated with H. pylori eradication therapy. Antibiotic resistance and/or inadequate adherence can lead to treatment failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is seen after a recent upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage that required care in the intensive care unit. One year ago, the patient was treated for H. pylori infection with triple therapy, including a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin, after he presented with dyspepsia and tested positive for H. pylori stool antigen. He has no history of use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications. A photograph of the endoscopic findings is shown. A biopsy of his stomach demonstrates chronic gastritis, with evidence of Helicobacter pylori organisms. Which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, levofloxacin, and clarithromycin
Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, misoprostol, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin
Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, and tetracycline
Repeat treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin
Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and amoxicillin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A levofloxacin-based regimen is another reasonable salvage regimen in someone with persistent H. pylori infection. However, this regimen consists of a proton pump inhibitor, levofloxacin, and amoxicillin (not clarithromycin).

B) INCORRECT:

Triple therapy consisting of a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin has traditionally been recommended as first-line therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. However, resistance to antibiotic treatment, particularly to clarithromycin, is increasing. As a result, clarithromycin should be avoided in first-line therapy in areas where macrolide resistance is high (likely to be the case for most of North America). Clarithromycin-based triple therapy can still be used as second-line treatment if initial treatment with first-line bismuth-based quadruple therapy fails to achieve eradication.

C) CORRECT:

Triple therapy consisting of a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin has traditionally been recommended as first-line therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. However, resistance to antibiotic treatment, particularly to clarithromycin, is increasing. As a result, clarithromycin should be avoided in first-line therapy in areas where macrolide resistance is high (likely to be the case for most of North America). Current guidelines recommend bismuth-based quadruple therapy, consisting of bismuth subsalicylate, a proton pump inhibitor, metronidazole, and tetracycline, for 10 to 14 days as first-line treatment for H. pylori infection. This regimen is also the most appropriate second-line treatment if initial treatment with triple therapy fails to eradicate the infection. Proton pump inhibitors are considered superior to histamine-2-receptor blockers for treating H. pylori infection.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for Helicobacter pylori infection is standard quadruple therapy (a proton pump inhibitor, bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, and tetracycline).

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat triple therapy with clarithromycin is not optimal because of the potential for the development of clarithromycin resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should not be used in this situation because H. pylori is naturally resistant to it.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with dark stools for the past week to the clinic. He recently began taking an over-the-counter medication for episodic heartburn and mild diarrhea. He denies abdominal pain, hematemesis, or changes in appetite. He has no past medical history and takes no other medications. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is benign. Fecal occult blood testing is negative. Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin level of 145 g/L (reference range, 130–170 g/L) and normal platelet count.
Which is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Start a proton pump inhibitor and repeat hemoglobin measurement in one week
Reassure that the stool discoloration is a harmless side effect of the over-the-counter medication
Discontinue the medication and perform a colonoscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dark stools can indicate upper gastrointestinal bleeding, but this patient is hemodynamically stable with a normal hemoglobin level and negative fecal occult blood test. These findings, along with recent medication use, suggest a benign cause for stool discoloration, making urgent endoscopy unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are used for acid-related mucosal injury, but the negative fecal occult blood test and normal hemoglobin level do not support gastrointestinal bleeding. The stool discoloration is likely a benign side effect of recent medication, not an indication for a PPI.

C) CORRECT:

Bismuth subsalicylate, used for mild diarrhea and heartburn, can cause stool discoloration by forming bismuth sulfide, a black compound. This is a benign effect, not indicative of gastrointestinal bleeding, as evidenced by the negative fecal occult blood test and normal hemoglobin level. Understanding this pharmacologic effect allows for reassurance without further invasive diagnostics.

Key learning point: Bismuth subsalicylate can cause non-tarry black stools due to the formation of bismuth sulfide, which is a harmless side effect.

D) INCORRECT:

While dark stools may suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, the negative fecal occult blood test and normal hemoglobin level indicate a benign cause, likely related to medication. Colonoscopy is invasive and reserved for cases with high suspicion of colonic pathology, which is not supported here.

questions.text: Three weeks after completing triple therapy for H. pylori, a 50-year-old man returns with persistent dyspepsia. He asks how best to confirm eradication. What is the single best next step?

choices.text: Urea breath test at least 4 weeks post-therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The urea breath test detects active Helicobacter pylori infection by measuring urease activity, which hydrolyzes labeled urea into measurable products. Performing the test at least 4 weeks after therapy completion is crucial to avoid false-negative results due to transient bacterial suppression by antibiotics. This timing ensures any surviving H. pylori organisms have repopulated, providing an accurate assessment of eradication status.

Key learning point: To accurately confirm Helicobacter pylori eradication, testing should be performed at least 4 weeks after completing therapy to avoid false-negative results.

B) INCORRECT:

The stool antigen test is reliable for confirming H. pylori eradication but should be performed at least 4 weeks post-therapy. Testing too soon, such as 2 weeks after treatment, risks false-negative results due to residual antibiotic effects and suppressed bacterial activity.

C) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing detects IgG antibodies to H. pylori, which can remain elevated for months after eradication. This persistence means the test may indicate past exposure rather than active infection, making it unreliable for confirming eradication shortly after treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate endoscopy with biopsy is invasive and typically reserved for patients with alarm features like gastrointestinal bleeding or suspected malignancy. It is not recommended for confirming H. pylori eradication shortly after therapy, as residual bacterial suppression from antibiotics and proton pump inhibitors can lead to false-negative results.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with concerns about persistent H. pylori infection. She has a 6-month history of intermittent epigastric discomfort and tested positive for H. pylori. She completed a 14-day course of triple therapy 6 weeks ago and reports improved symptoms. She denies any significant past medical history and takes no other medications. Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate non-invasive test to confirm eradication of her H. pylori infection?

choices.text: Endoscopic biopsy with rapid urease test
Serologic measurement of H. pylori IgG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic biopsy with rapid urease test is invasive and typically used for initial diagnosis in patients with indications for endoscopy. It is not suitable for routine post-treatment follow-up due to its invasive nature and potential complications. Non-invasive tests are preferred for confirming eradication.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum gastrin measurement is influenced by various factors, such as proton pump inhibitor use and atrophic gastritis, and does not directly assess H. pylori presence. It provides an indirect measure of gastric physiology, which may remain abnormal post-eradication, making it unreliable for confirming treatment success.

C) INCORRECT:

Serologic measurement of H. pylori IgG is non-invasive and useful for initial diagnosis, but IgG antibodies can persist long after eradication, up to 18 months. This persistence makes it unreliable for confirming eradication, as a positive result may indicate past exposure rather than active infection.

D) CORRECT:

The urea breath test detects active Helicobacter pylori infection by measuring labeled carbon dioxide in the breath after ingestion of labeled urea. H. pylori produces urease, which hydrolyzes urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. This test is highly sensitive and specific, distinguishing active infection from residual antibodies. Performing the test at least four weeks post-therapy ensures accuracy by reflecting ongoing infection rather than recent treatment effects. Its non-invasive nature makes it ideal for confirming H. pylori eradication.

Key learning point: The urea breath test is the most appropriate non-invasive test to confirm eradication of H. pylori after treatment due to its high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the Outpatient Clinic with persistent mild dyspepsia. He has a 6-month history of intermittent epigastric pain and tested positive for Helicobacter pylori via endoscopic biopsy. He completed a 14-day course of clarithromycin-based triple therapy six weeks ago. He denies weight loss or melena. Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness without guarding. Blood tests, including hemoglobin 135 g/L (reference 130–170 g/L), are normal. Recent stool analysis was unremarkable. He is concerned about treatment failure and requests a definitive non-invasive method to confirm that the Helicobacter pylori infection has been successfully eradicated.
Which of the following is the single best test to confirm eradication in this scenario?

choices.text: Serologic testing for anti-H. pylori IgG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stool culture for H. pylori is impractical and not validated for eradication assessment. The organism is difficult to culture from stool due to its fastidious nature and the complex flora present. Non-invasive methods detecting bacterial antigens or metabolic activity are preferred for post-treatment evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

The ¹³C-urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method to confirm Helicobacter pylori eradication. It relies on the urease enzyme activity of H. pylori. When a patient ingests ¹³C-labeled urea, active infection results in the production of ¹³CO₂, detectable in the breath. This test has high sensitivity and specificity, especially when performed at least 4 weeks post-treatment, reducing false negatives from transient bacterial suppression. It effectively distinguishes active infection from past exposure, making it ideal for post-treatment monitoring.

Key learning point: The 13C-Urea-breath test is the most appropriate non-invasive method to monitor the eradication of H. pylori infection after treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat endoscopic biopsy, while definitive, is invasive and unnecessary for a patient with mild dyspepsia and no alarm features. The patient seeks a non-invasive method, and endoscopy carries risks like bleeding. It is reserved for cases with suspected complications or malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing for anti-H. pylori IgG is unsuitable for confirming eradication because antibody levels can remain elevated long after successful treatment. This test indicates past exposure rather than active infection, making it unreliable for assessing current infection status or treatment response.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 1-day history of black, tarry stools. He also reports upper abdominal pain that occurs immediately after eating and a 4.4-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. He has no significant past medical history but drinks 3 beers daily. His only medication is acetaminophen. He works as a financial consultant and travels frequently. His partner was recently diagnosed with a positive urea breath test and started treatment 2 weeks ago. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals a bleeding 15-mm ulcer in the antrum of the stomach. Which one of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen is a commonly used nonopioid analgesic. Although it can cause gastrointestinal side effects such as nausea and vomiting, it does not increase the risk of PUD or gastrointestinal bleeding. In comparison, NSAIDs, another class of commonly used nonopioid analgesic, can increase the risk of PUD 5-fold.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol consumption increases the risk of PUD by causing chemical gastritis, which predisposes individuals to ulcer development and prolongs ulcer healing. However, alcohol consumption is not the strongest predisposing factor for PUD in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Although age is a predisposing factor for PUD, the risk is significantly higher in individuals over the age of 65 years, whereas it would only be marginally increased in a 45-year-old patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Stress has been associated with increased gastric acid production and development of PUD, although the exact underlying mechanism is poorly understood and causality has not yet been defined. A different predisposing factor is more likely in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori infection is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's PUD. H. pylori infection accounts for up to 25–50% of gastric ulcers and 40–70% of duodenal ulcers. The most common sites for ulcer development are the lesser curvature and the antrum of the stomach and the duodenal bulb, and diagnosis of H. pylori infection can be confirmed on biopsy. In addition to controlling bleeding, treatment of his peptic ulcer should include H. pylori eradication therapy, proton pump inhibitors, and avoidance of NSAIDs and alcohol consumption.

H. pylori infection also increases the risk of gastric cancer and mucosa-associated lymphatic tissue (MALT) lymphoma.

Key learning point: Helicobacter pylori infection is the strongest predisposing factor for peptic ulcer disease, accounting for a significant proportion of both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
questions.hint: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) involves visualization and biopsy of the upper gastrointestinal tract, and it, therefore, confirms the diagnosis. EGD is also useful in taking simultaneous therapeutic measures (e.g., electrocautery for active bleeding).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-year history of recurrent upper abdominal pain and fullness that worsens after meals. Urea breath test is positive. Endoscopy shows diffuse mucosal atrophy and patchy erythema, but no ulcer. Which one of the following biopsy sites is most likely to yield an accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The pylorus is not a common site for atrophic gastritis or for colonization by H. pylori. Pyloric biopsies would be indicated in patients with a pyloric mass causing gastric outlet obstruction. Although this man has early satiety, he lacks other symptoms consistent with gastric outlet obstruction, such as postprandial, nonbilious vomiting, progressive gastric dilation, and weight loss.

B) INCORRECT:

H. pylori-induced atrophic gastritis can cause mucosal changes in the fundus, making it an important location to biopsy when H. pylori gastritis is suspected but the heaviest infection with H. pylori is usually seen in another location. The gastric fundus and body are primarily affected in autoimmune atrophic gastritis, which can present similarly but the urea breath test would be negative and other features suggestive of autoimmune disease (e.g., pernicious anemia, vitiligo, autoimmune thyroiditis) would usually be present.

C) INCORRECT:

The duodenal bulb is a common location for duodenal ulcers, which are often associated with H. pylori infection. However, upper endoscopy findings in this patient show diffuse gastric mucosal atrophy and inflammation without an ulcer, which is consistent with chronic atrophic gastritis rather than peptic ulcer disease. A different site has the heaviest H. pylori infection load in patients with chronic atrophic gastritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Distal esophageal biopsies are indicated in patients with treatment-resistant reflux esophagitis to rule out Barrett esophagus and dysplastic changes. Atrophic gastritis due to H. pylori infection requires a biopsy from a different gastric site, as the esophagus does not typically exhibit the highest H. pylori load or the most pronounced atrophic changes.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic atrophic gastritis due to H. pylori infection begins in the gastric antrum (pyloric antrum) and then spreads to other regions such as the fundus and body. Biopsies from the gastric antrum are therefore most likely to yield an accurate diagnosis because atrophic changes and H. pylori infection load is greatest at this site. Gastric MALToma is a potential complication of H. pylori infection. In contrast to H. pylori-induced atrophic gastritis, the gastric fundus and body are primarily affected in autoimmune atrophic gastritis, which can present similarly but the urea breath test would be negative and other features suggestive of autoimmune disease (e.g., pernicious anemia, vitiligo, autoimmune thyroiditis) would usually be present. Patients with atrophic gastritis have decreased gastric acid secretion (hypochlorhydria) with a secondary increase in gastrin levels.

Persistent dyspepsia in a patient over 55 years of age mandates evaluation with an upper endoscopy, even in the absence of alarm symptoms (dysphagia, unintentional weight loss, hematemesis, or melena), to rule out malignant lesions.

Key learning point: Chronic atrophic gastritis due to Helicobacter pylori most commonly begins in the gastric antrum, making this the preferred biopsy site for accurate diagnosis.
